(57) 10th Conclusions, Minute l) discussions have takenplace on the authorised basis of a minimum offer of 8 millions. the farmers Unions have asked for 19 millions, which includes an increase of-fd. a gallon on milk, and 6d. a score on pigs, and a reduction of no morethan Id. a dozen on eggs. Further they have now said that no agreement is possible on the basis of the maximum reduction of l^d. on eggs and nochange in the guaranteed prices for milk and pigs (i. e. the original offer on these three commodities, apart from an advance of 6d. on pigs).2. If a settleme?rt is to be agreed it is now clear that a total award of at least 15 millions, including jd. a gallon increase in the guaranteed price of milk, will be necessary.3. If we are to make no further advance on milk the settlement mustbe imposed, and there are three figures on which the total award could bebased:-(a)(b)(o)P.T.D.H.A.f4*COPY NO.CABINET 8 millions - the minimum permissible under thelong t erm assurances - to be justified by thepresent financial circumstances. 10 millions - to be justified as above the minimum and making possible through no change in the priceof pigs some gesture towards the small farmer. 13 millions - to be justified as objectivelydefensible.6th March, 1957.
